greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the smallest k such that prime(k) contains the digits of k in their order.
link: Giovanni Resta, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
Index entries for primes involving decimal expansion of n
example: 0 appears first in 26th prime (101), so a(0) = 26;
9 appears first in 8th prime (19), so a(9) = 8;
24 appears first in 53rd prime (241), so a(24) = 53.
mathematica: tg=101; T=0*Range[tg]; k=0; subs[n_] := Block[{d = IntegerDigits[n]}, Flatten@ Table[ FromDigits@ Take[d, {i, j}], {j, Length[d]}, {i, j}]]; While[tg > 0, s = subs[Prime[++k]]; Do[ If[e <= 100 && T[[e+1]] == 0, T[[e+1]] = k; tg--], {e, s}]]; T (* _Giovanni Resta_, Apr 29 2017 *)
results.author: _Labos Elemer_, Apr 03 2003
